description.narrative:
This programme element concerns the Kabul Country Office budget for coordination and support activities related to the My Rigth My Voice multi country, which is jointly managed by OGB and ON and implemented by national partners. The work of both Oxfam GB (OGB) and Oxfam Novib (ON) in Afghanistan on health and education has a rights based approach with a central focus on 'children and youth' as rights holders and key agents of change. The joint youth health and education project is building on this work and aims to leverage the knowledge, experience and relationships established by OGB and ON to build on both longstanding work and new innovative approaches.
The overall goal of the Afghanistan projects is to contribute to achieving the millennium development goals on education and health in Afghanistan through the building of a strong youth movement. The purpose of the projects is to promote youth as change agents at the local and national level in contributing to policy changes and improvements and enhanced access to quality health and education.
For ON Afghanistan the Afghan Civil Society Forum (ACSFo) is the partner. The ACSFo contribution to the programme will focus on the education sector and only address health and sanitation aspects directly related to education.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to basic social services
